description: Borrowed from Late Latin histriōnicus (“pertaining to acting; scurrilous, shameful; wretched”), from Latin histriōnicus (“pertaining to acting and the theatre”), from histriō (“actor, player”) + -icus (suffix meaning ‘of or pertaining to’). Morphologically, the word may be surface analysed as histrion +‎ -ic.

adjectives.description: histrionic (comparative more histrionic, superlative most histrionic)

entries.meaning: Of or relating to actors or acting.
(by extension) Excessively dramatic or emotional, especially with the intention to draw attention.
